name: Antimicrobial prescribing for human and animal bites
rules: IF a bite has not broken the skin, THEN do not offer antibiotics.
IF a human bite has broken the skin but not drawn blood in a high-risk area or person at high risk, THEN consider antibiotics.
IF a human bite has broken the skin and drawn blood, THEN offer antibiotics.
IF a cat bite has not broken the skin, THEN do not offer antibiotics.
IF a cat bite has broken the skin but not drawn blood if the wound could be deep, THEN consider antibiotics.
IF a cat bite has broken the skin and drawn blood, THEN offer antibiotics.
IF a dog or other traditional pet bite has not broken the skin, THEN do not offer antibiotics.
IF a dog or other traditional pet bite has broken the skin but not drawn blood, THEN do not offer antibiotics.
IF a dog or other traditional pet bite has caused considerable, deep tissue damage or is visibly contaminated, THEN offer antibiotics.
IF a dog or other traditional pet bite is in a high-risk area or person at high risk, THEN consider antibiotics.
IF there are signs of a serious illness such as severe cellulitis, abscess, osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, necrotising fasciitis, or sepsis, THEN refer to hospital.
IF there is a penetrating wound involving bones, joints, tendons, or vascular structures, THEN refer to hospital.
IF a person is systemically unwell or has an infection after prophylactic antibiotics, THEN consider referral or seeking specialist advice.
IF a person cannot take or has an infection that is not responding to oral antibiotics, THEN consider referral or seeking specialist advice.
IF a bite wound does not start to improve within 24 to 48 hours of starting treatment, THEN reassess.
IF symptoms or signs of the infection develop or worsen rapidly at any time, THEN reassess.
IF a person becomes systemically unwell or there is severe pain disproportionate to the infection, THEN reassess.
IF the type of bite is from a wild or exotic animal, THEN seek specialist advice from a microbiologist.
IF the type of bite is from a domestic animal unfamiliar to the practitioner, THEN consider seeking specialist advice.
IF providing prophylaxis, THEN prescribe first-choice oral antibiotic Co-amoxiclav based on the age and infection severity.
IF Co-amoxiclav is unsuitable due to penicillin allergy, THEN prescribe doxycycline and metronidazole, or seek specialist advice for alternative.
IF prescribing for children under 1 month old, THEN seek specialist advice.
IF prescribing for pregnancy with penicillin allergy or if co-amoxiclav is unsuitable, THEN seek specialist advice.
IF using intravenous antibiotics and a cephalosporin is inappropriate, THEN seek specialist advice.
